webTitle: Government verdict on no-deal Brexit: food price hikes, Dover delays and £13bn cost to business - as it happened

fields.headline: Government verdict on no-deal Brexit: food price hikes, Dover delays and £13bn cost to business - as it happened
fields.standfirst:
Brexit department publishes the government’s assessment of the impact of a no-deal Brexit on the UK

  • MPs will get vote on extending article 50 if no deal agreed, PM says
  • May’s Commons statement - Summary
  • May’s statement and the reaction - Snap analysis
  • Summary of government report on impact of no-deal Brexit
fields.trailText: Brexit department publishes the government’s assessment of the impact of a no-deal Brexit on the UK
fields.body:
8.03pm GMT

Closing summary

Here’s a summary of the day’s latest events:

  • A no-deal Brexit is likely to have profound consequences for the UK, according to a government assessment. The report says food prices would probably increase, extra customs checks could cost business £13bn a year and there is little evidence firms are ready for the changeover, among other dire warnings.
  • A senior EU diplomat said the UK would be facing “guaranteed no deal” if MPs fail to back a Brexit agreement at the end of a three-month extension period. EU officials think 1 July is the final day the UK could remain an EU member state without taking part in European elections.
  • Jeremy Corbyn faced some opposition to his plan to back a second referendum. According to a report, some shadow cabinet members were upset at the politics pf the move – and at having first heard about it via media reports.
  • And here’s a summary of Theresa May’s statement this afternoon.

We’re going to close down this live blog now – thanks for reading and for all the comments. For more details on the government’s no-deal Brexit imapct analysis, my colleague Lisa O’Carroll has the full story:

Related: Economy could be 9% weaker under no-deal Brexit, government says

7.17pm GMT

The DUP’s leader and deputy leader, Arlene Foster and Nigel Dodds, met the prime minister this afternoon in May’s House of Commons office. Afterwards, Foster said:

We support a sensible deal and a managed exit from the European Union. Parliament has mandated the prime minister to seek a replacement of the backstop. At that time, the prime minister committed to seek legally binding changes to the withdrawal agreement. This position commanded a clear majority in parliament. Mrs May should deliver on those commitments.

Experience in Northern Ireland has shown that extending deadlines does nothing to encourage a deal.

A no-deal outcome can be avoided and it can be agreed long before 29 March. The European Union have it in their hands to avoid such an outcome. They know exactly what is required to achieve a deal which parliament can support.

It’s time for Dublin and Brussels to be in a deal-making mode.

Updated at 7.45pm GMT

7.08pm GMT

As Leslie mentioned, Labour has said it will back moves to set up a second referendum if it cannot force Theresa May to adandon her deal and adopt its Brexit stance this week.

But the party’s leader, Jeremy Corbyn, is facing problems of his own on that front:

My colleagues, Heather Stewart and Jessica Elgot, have the full story:

Related: Labour backlash expected over support for second referendum

And Politics Home has this:

... At the Shadow Cabinet meeting, normally-loyal frontbenchers lined up to attack the plan.

Shadow Justice Secretary Richard Burgon complained about the fact that the whole Shadow Cabinet had not been involved in the decision and added: “Why did we hear about it in the media?”

Labour chairman Ian Lavery, a long-standing opponent of a second referendum, said the new policy was “political suicide”, while Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey and Shadow Cabinet Office minister Jon Trickett also criticised the move.

Leave-backing Labour MPs have already demanded that Mr Corbyn give his troops a free vote on any second referendum amendment.

Meanwhile, Shadow Cabinet members also lined up to attack deputy leader Tom Watson for calling on Labour MPs to notify him if they make complaints anout anti-semitism or bullying by party members.

Diane Abbott and Emily Thornberry were among those who criticised the move, saying he should not be setting up “a shadow complaints process”.

In response, Mr Watson said he was trying to hold the party together following the resignations of nine Labour MPs in the past week.

You can read the full article here.

Updated at 7.13pm GMT

6.59pm GMT

Speaking of the Independent Group, its MPs have tabled a cross-party amendment to pave the way for a second EU referendum – with the support of MPs in the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Plaid Cymru.

The amendment, for debate in the Commons on Wednesday, would instruct the prime minister to table a motion for debate and decision before 8 March, setting out the steps necessary for preparing a public vote on whether to leave the EU on terms agreed by parliament or remain a member. Chris Leslie, of TIG, has said:

At this eleventh hour, it’s vital that preparations take place for a People’s Vote.

This cross-party amendment would require the prime minister to take the steps needed now so the public could take control and break through the Brexit gridlock. There is no more time to waste.

With Labour now signalling it may support a confirmatory referendum in the weeks ahead, there is no reason to hold back on vital measures to pave the way. If the Labour leadership support this amendment, we could make real progress on a People’s Vote.

Now is the time to put the national interest first. Parliament must act now.

6.42pm GMT

Chuka Umunna, who now sits in parliament with the Independent Group of MPs, says the government’s assessment of the impact of a no-deal Brexit demonstrate that it would “be a catastrophe”.

These documents, which the Independent Group of MPs have forced this government to publish, paint a disastrous picture of the catastrophe which would befall our country if there is a no-deal Brexit. In light of what she knows, it is utterly irresponsible for the prime minister to keep a no-deal Brexit on the table, given the extreme damage it will do. These papers set out how food prices will rise, we may see panic buying, there will be severe disruption at the border, and jobs and livelihoods would immediately be put at risk.

Today, she told the House of Commons she is listening but MPs have passed a motion rejecting a no-deal Brexit and yet she refuses to request an extension of the Article 50 process in order to stop no-deal happening. The prime minister is refusing to face down the hard-right extremists in her own party and put the national interest first. This is yet more evidence of our broken politics. We have no choice but to change it.

Updated at 10.42am GMT

6.36pm GMT

The Labour MP, Chris Williamson, faces a dressing down from party officials after he helped to arrange a screening in parliament of a film defending Jackie Walker, an activist suspended from the party over comments about antisemitism.

A party spokeswoman said it was “completely inappropriate” for the Derby North MP to have booked a room in parliament next Monday for a screening of the film, titled Witch Hunt.

Labour’s chief whip, Nick Brown, and the general secretary, Jennie Formby, are set to contact Williamson to stress their displeasure at his actions, and to ensure he cancels the booking.

Witch Hunt takes a sceptical look at claims that Labour has experienced a problem with some antisemitic behaviour under Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership, focusing particularly on the case of Walker, who has been suspended from the party for more than two years.

Walker was initially suspended after she wrote about Jewish people as “financiers of the sugar and slave trade”, but was then reinstated. She was suspended again in September 2016 after saying she had not found a definition of antisemitism she could work with, and questioning why Holocaust Memorial Day was not more wide-ranging. She is reportedly facing a party hearing next month.

The Labour spokeswoman said:

It’s completely inappropriate to book a room for an event about an individual who is suspended from the party and subject to ongoing disciplinary procedures. This falls below the standards we expect of MPs.

6.23pm GMT

Responding to the prime minister’s statement earlier this afternoon, the Labour MP Yvette Cooper has said:

Parliament has forced the prime minister to agree to votes which can prevent a damaging and chaotic no deal – this is extremely important.

As a result of our cross-party arguments and Bill, the prime minister today accepted most of the provisions of the Bill to provide for votes that can avert no deal on 29 March and extend Article 50 if there is no agreement in place.

We have laid a new cross-party amendment to pin down and confirm the commitment made by the prime minister today to hold these votes and ensure that we do not just drift into a chaotic no deal.

We have also laid the cross-party paving amendment for the Bill to ensure there is no backtracking from anyone in the cabinet or in the debate tomorrow on the prime minister’s commitments. And we have tabled a third amendment to make time for a further day for Commons debate where additional amendments and options can be voted on.

We will keep up the pressure on the government to prevent a chaotic no deal. The prime minister has not yet said how she or the government would vote on a no deal motion – that is irresponsible, as no deal would be deeply damaging for manufacturing, medicine supplies and food prices. The government should say now that they would vote against no deal as that would provide additional reassurance for businesses, public services and families currently struggling to prepare for no deal.

5.56pm GMT

Higher food prices, significant delays at Dover for months, an extra £13bn in costs for business – government verdict on no-deal Brexit

The government’s document about the impact of a no-deal Brexit (pdf) does not seem as alarmist as Anna Soubry, the MP who demanded it, suggested it might be. She wanted to see the briefing paper on this topic supplied to cabinet. The government agreed to publish not the actual paper, but a summary of its contents, and it reads as if it has been drafted so as not to sound too shocking.

Still, even the civil service language cannot disguise the fact that it is saying some of the no-deal consequences would be profound. Here are some highlights.

  • The report says the flow of goods through Dover would be “very significantly reduced for months” under a no-deal Brexit.

In particular, third country rules applied by the EU, including France, would mean that no goods are allowed to leave the port until they have provided the correct paperwork and have been customs cleared (including any necessary checks at the port, for example on products of animal origin). More significantly, member states would hold any goods which are not correctly customs cleared. This would hold up all goods where trades are not prepared, expected to be a significant proportion in the early period after exit day. The government’s worst case planning assumption is that, as a result of French checks and lack of businesses readiness, the flow of goods through the short channel crossings (Dover and Eurotunnel) could be very significantly reduced for months.

  • It says food prices would probably increase.

At the time of year we will be leaving the EU, the UK is particularly reliant on the short channel crossings for fresh fruit and vegetables. In the absence of other action from government, some food prices are likely to increase, and there is a risk that consumer behaviour could exacerbate, or create, shortages in this scenario. As of February 2019, many businesses in the food supply industry are unprepared for a no deal scenario.

  • It says there is “little evidence” that businesses are ready for a no-deal Brexit, and that small and medium-sized enterprises are particularly vulnerable.

Despite communications from the government, there is little evidence that businesses are preparing in earnest for a no deal scenario, and evidence indicates that readiness of small and medium-sized enterprises in particular is low. For example, without an Economic Operator Registration and Identification (EORI) number, businesses would not be able to complete the necessary customs documentation for goods they are importing. As an EORI number registration is one of the most basic and straightforward parts of the process most businesses would need to undertake to prepare for no deal, this is assumed to be a generous indicator of overall readiness. As of February 2019 there had only been around 40,000 registrations for an EORI number, against an estimate of around 240,000 EU-only trading businesses. There is capacity to sign up 11,000 businesses per day, and so this position could change rapidly with behaviour change from businesses.

  • It says extra customs checks alone could cost business £13bn a year under a no-deal Brexit.

In a no-deal scenario, both the UK and EU would need to apply customs and excise rules and VAT to goods moving between the UK and EU, as they are currently applied to goods traded in the rest of the world. Every consignment would require a customs declaration, and so around 240,000 UK businesses that currently only trade with the EU would need to interact with customs processes for the first time, should they continue to trade with the EU. HMRC has estimated that the administrative burden on businesses from customs declarations alone, on current (2016) UK-EU trade in goods could be around £13bn pa (not accounting for any behavioural change).

  • It says it is impossible to predict the impact of new tariffs on businesses.

Industries would need to respond to the application of EU tariffs. These would vary by sector. While for some sectors (such as life sciences or electronics) the effect of any tariffs would be minor, other sectors would be more affected. For example, the EU would introduce tariffs of around 70% on beef and 45% on lamb exports, and 10% on finished automotive vehicles. This would be compounded by the challenges of even modest reductions in flow at the border. Given the unprecedented nature of the sort of economy-wide adjustment that would be required in a no-deal scenario, it is impossible to accurately predict the ability of businesses to adapt.

  • It says businesses in Northern Ireland could go bust.

In a no-deal scenario there is an expectation of disruption to closely interwoven supply chains and increasing costs that would affect the viability of many businesses across Northern Ireland. There is a risk that businesses in Northern Ireland will not have sufficient time to prepare. This could result in business failure, and/or relocation to Ireland with knock-on consequences for the Northern Ireland economy and unemployment. Northern Ireland is particularly vulnerable given its high proportion of, and reliance upon SMEs (75% of all private sector employment) and the number of businesses who trade directly with Ireland (Northern Ireland’s largest international export market). The agri-food sector is a disproportionately large part of Northern Ireland’s economy and located predominantly in border/rural areas. It is particularly vulnerable given its reliance on cross-border supply chains in the production stage and in finished products.

  • It confirms that some EU trade deals would not be able to carry over after Brexit.

A number of the most critical international agreements have been signed and are on track to come into force on exit day, including on aviation and civil nuclear cooperation and safeguarding. Those that are not may not be in force on exit day. If contingency options were not in place, there would be a gap in coverage for some international agreements, the impact of which would vary depending on the nature and scale of the agreement.

Around 40 of these agreements are trade agreements. To date, the government has signed trade agreements with Switzerland, Chile, the Faroe Islands, members of the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) Economic Partnership Agreement, Israel and the Palestinian Authority ... if the UK leaves the EU without a deal, some agreements will not be concluded in time and therefore will not be in place for exit day. Agreements which will clearly not be in place for exit day are Andorra, Japan, Turkey, and San Marino; the government has set out further details in published guidance.

  • It says Britons travelling to the EU could be subject to full Schengen checks.

In the absence of an alternative agreement, UK citizens would be treated as third country nationals by member states, and potentially be subject to full Schengen checks. This would mean they would no longer be able to use e-gates, and checks to enter EU member states could take longer than they currently do.

That’s all from me for tonight.

My colleague Kevin Rawlinson is now taking over.

Updated at 6.05pm GMT

5.16pm GMT

Government publishes its assessment of impact of no-deal Brexit

The Brexit department has just published the government’s assessment of the impact of a no-deal Brexit. It is here (pdf).

5.14pm GMT

Jacob Rees-Mogg, the chairman of the European Research Group, which represents 50 or more of the most hardline Brexiters, has posted this tweet with a clip from his interview on Sky News earlier.

Here is his quote in full.

If Brexit were to be delayed to change the backstop to the Malthouse compromise, that would be positive. And to allow time for legislation to get through - that again would be perfectly acceptable.

If it is being delayed, which is my suspicion, as a plot to stop Brexit altogether, then I think that would be the most grievous error that politicians could commit. It would be overthrowing the referendum result, two general elections, one to call for the referendum, one to endorse the referendum, and would undermine our democracy.

This implies that the ERG are in full outrage mode about Theresa May’s decision.

But Rees-Mogg has erected a straw man to denounce. No one seriously thinks May wants to stop Brexit altogether. Some MPs would like to do this, but they don’t include the leaders of either of the main parties.

Elsewhere in his interview Rees-Mogg sounded much less perturbed by May’s announcement. At another point he said:

There is no evidence that a new deal can be agreed that would be acceptable to parliament in that period [between 29 March, the current Brexit date, and 30 June, the latest date for Brexit implied by May’s statement]. So the cliff edge, if that is the term people want to use, has merely been moved back. And there is no willingness to delay beyond the new European parliament forming. So it [May’s offer] doesn’t offer parliament very much.

And when he was asked whether ERG members might be more inclined to vote for May’s deal as a result of today’s announcement, to prevent article 50 being extended, he replied:

This brinksmanship, this effort of ‘call my bluff’, is not going to change people’s minds to back her deal.

Updated at 5.46pm GMT

5.02pm GMT

Here is the text of the government motion for tomorrow’s Brexit debate.

4.50pm GMT

I don’t often do reader requests, but in the comments BTL Exordium2190 said Ken Clarke’s intervention during the statement should have been included. So here it is in full. This is what Clarke said:

May I congratulate the prime minister on accepting that we are not remotely ready for the chaos of a no-deal departure on 29 March? I agree with her that no deal at any time would bring very damaging medium and long-term prospects for the British economy and our wellbeing. I will continue to vote for any withdrawal agreement that she manages to get with the other EU countries, but I doubt that she will command a majority for any such agreement in the near future.

Can I turn to the real issue now? How long is the delay that we are contemplating? The prime minister seems to be giving us a date for a new cliff edge at the end of June, but is not the danger that we will merely continue the present pantomime performance through the next three months, and that the public will be dismayed as we approach that date and find that there is similar chaos about where we are going?

May I suggest that we contemplate a much calmer delay, that we have indicative votes following debates in this House, to see where a consensus or majority lies, and then that we prepare our position for the much more important long-term negotiations that have to take place on the eventual settlement? We cannot have several more years of what we have had for the past two years. We have to start proper negotiations with the EU on what exactly we contemplate as our long-term relationships with the union.

In response, Theresa May just said that she did not want an extension and that, if there had to be one, it should be “as short as possible”.

Updated at 5.19pm GMT

4.38pm GMT

The most emotional appeal to Theresa May during her statement came from the Labour MP Jess Phillips. Here it is.

Updated at 4.51pm GMT

4.33pm GMT

This BBC graphic is quite useful.

4.08pm GMT

The Labour MP Yvette Cooper says she will go ahead and table her amendment today. But she says Theresa May has conceded “most” of what the amendment wants, and implies that if she receives further assurances tomorrow, she will not put it to a vote.

Updated at 4.25pm GMT

4.00pm GMT

This is from ITV’s Daniel Hewitt.

3.56pm GMT

The Spectator’s James Forsyth has posted a short but revealing blog about today’s cabinet. Here’s an extract.

There was considerable anger at Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke for how they have heaped pressure on May to offer this vote on a delay if the meaningful vote fails on 12 March. Liz Truss labelled them ‘kamikaze cabinet ministers’ and Andrea Leadsom was, I’m told, audibly furious. Brandon Lewis, Julian Smith, Jeremy Wright, Damian Hinds and James Brokenshire all criticised the way this trio had behaved.

Updated at 4.25pm GMT

3.53pm GMT

The Times’ Sam Coates says a no-deal Brexit may be more likely after Theresa May’s announcement today.

3.47pm GMT

Sir Oliver Letwin, the Conservative former cabinet minister who has been one of the main supporters of the Yvette Cooper bill, has said he thinks it is no longer necessary.

3.45pm GMT

The UK would be facing “guaranteed no deal” if MPs fail to back a Brexit agreement at the end of a three-month extension period, a senior EU diplomat has told the Guardian.

EU officials think 1 July is the final day the UK could remain an EU member state without taking part in European elections. A three-month extension of article 50 to the end of June, coupled with no European elections in the UK in May, would make it impossible for the UK to continue as a member state, according to EU sources. The new parliament begins its work on 2 July.

“It will be a no-return situation. If there is no solution then it is a guaranteed no deal,” the senior diplomat said.

The source expressed scepticism that a divided House of Commons would find in three months the consensus that has eluded MPs for more than two and a half years.

There would be a doubt; it’s difficult to imagine. If people cannot agree now, why would it be possible in three months? That being said, I don’t see that the heads of state and government would say no [to a three-month extension]. Probably they will say ‘let’s do that, let’s give them a last chance’.

During a three-month extension period, the EU would “accelerate the no-deal planning” the source added.

Three months maximum and then it’s clear for everyone that it is the only extension, the first and the last. Then the UK would not have European elections, it would have to finalise everything.

The EU is open to longer extensions, with various options mooted from nine to 21 months. The longer option, until the end of 2020, is seen by some senior EU insiders as a political tactic designed by the European commission to frighten the European Research Group of Tory Eurosceptics into voting for the withdrawal agreement.

Updated at 4.27pm GMT

3.38pm GMT

This is from Nick Boles, one of the Tories backing the Yvette Cooper amendment. He seems to be saying that, although the amendment will still be tabled, if ministers offer sufficient assurances in the debate tomorrow, it may not be put to a vote.

3.26pm GMT

May's statement and the reaction – snap analysis

At the start of this week there were claims that tomorrow’s vote would mark the moment when Theresa May, finally, had to make a choice between siding with the pro-Europeans in her government or the European Research Group (ERG), the faction in her party pushing for a harder Brexit. But not for the first time, predictions about May being forced to commit have turned out to be misplaced. Her capacity for equivocation is extraordinary.

I summarised the main announcements in her statement at 2.02pm. But here are some thoughts on the political consequences.

1) An extension of article 50 has, within the space of a week, gone from something that the government would scarcely discuss in public to a firm probability. May has announced a mechanism for how it might happen. And if, as the BBC’s Katya Adler argues (see 12.04pm), May was hoping to use “three-way Brexit blackmail” to encourage Brexiters, Labour and the EU to compromise ahead of the “meaningful vote”, by creating a mechanism for an article 50 extension she has weakened the leverage that might help get her deal through parliament – making extension even more likely.

2) As usual, May is treating EU thinking as an afterthought. May wants to let MPs vote for a short, one-off article 50 extension if her deal gets voted down. (Quite whether, in practice, she would be able to stop parliament pushing for a second extension is another matter.) But EU leaders have been clear that they would support either a short extension to allow MPs to pass the legislation needed to facilitate Brexit, or a long extension needed to allow the UK to make up its mind. A short extension to allow the UK to dither for three more months holds little attraction for them, and it is not obvious that that they would even agree. (For article 50 to be extended, the EU27 would have to support this unanimously.)

3) May seems to have done enough to avert government resignations. MPs are still mulling over what she said, but the early indications are that she has done enough to satisfy those Tories who were planning to resign from government to back the Cooper amendment. Indeed, it is not even certain at this point whether the Cooper amendment will still be put to a vote.

4) Cleverly, May has also managed to appease the remainers without unduly provoking the ERG leavers. During her statement, it was striking how little criticism she received from Tory Brexiters, who until recently would have viewed any talk of an article 50 extension as a betrayal. It may just be that they are holding their fire. But equally it may be that, as Jacob Rees-Mogg suggested in an interview earlier (see 1.27pm), they have concluded that May has not removed no deal as a prospect, but just delayed the point at which it might happen.

4) But not so cleverly, May has just perpetuated the uncertainty. May won’t even commit the government to whipping its MPs to vote for an article 50 extension if her deal fails and, as my colleague Heather Stewart points out (see 2.37pm), this does not make life any easier for businesses trying to work out how seriously they need to take the risk of no deal. She seems to have pulled off a modest tactical success, while doing nothing to edge her party, or parliament, any closer to a long-term resolution of this crisis.

Updated at 3.42pm GMT

2.55pm GMT

MPs received a surprise in the House of Commons earlier when Theresa May used a catchphrase from a car insurance advert to explain the options on Brexit. As the Press Association reported, the prime minister quoted Compare the Market’s TV ad to the SNP’s Westminster leader, Ian Blackford, who claimed May was “running down the clock” before the UK’s departure from the EU. Blackford accused the prime minister of wasting nine days of parliamentary time after she announced she was giving MPs a vote on delaying the Brexit departure date past 29 March. Responding, May said:

If he wants to end the uncertainty … then he should vote for a deal. Simples.

Politicians said they were “stunned” by the quote, with the Labour MP Rupa Huq tweeting:

Updated at 3.38pm GMT

2.49pm GMT

This is from the Telegraph’s Christopher Hope.

2.48pm GMT

And ITV’s Robert Peston says Sir Oliver Letwin, another leading Tory supporter of the Cooper amendment, is satisfied with what May has promised.

2.47pm GMT

Theresa May has finally finished her statement. She was on her feet for just over two hours. I will post a snap analysis shortly.

2.43pm GMT

Nick Boles, one of the Conservative MPs who voted for the Cooper amendment last month, seems to be happy with Theresa May’s offer.

Yvette Cooper sounded far less happy with May’s assurances when she spoke in the Commons earlier (see 1.19pm), but she has not said yet whether she will go ahead with her amendment and press it to a vote.

Updated at 2.54pm GMT

2.37pm GMT

Downing Street refuses to commit government backing article 50 extension if May's deal defeated

Briefing journalists after the prime minister’s statement, her spokesman repeatedly - and maddeningly - refused to say how the government would whip its MPs if it has to call a vote on 14 March on whether article 50 should be extended. He said:

I think what you heard in the Commons was the prime minister’s absolute determination to get a deal over the line in a way that the House of Commons can support it. That is her focus and that is what you would expect.

Questions on whipping on what may or may not follow that are for another day. I think it’s important that we set these things out in order.

Asked what length of extension the government will recommend, if her deal fails and MPs reject no deal, he pointed to the PM’s words saying it would be “as short as possible” - and declined to say what the government would do to if MPs amend the motion to demand a longer period.

Pressed on whether May was still willing to take Britain out of the EU without a deal, he said “she wouldn’t give parliament a vote if she wasn’t willing to abide by it.”

But the conversation underlined the fact that what the PM has announced today is not “taking no deal off the table”; she has simply accepted that if it comes to the crunch, she will allow MPs to bind her hands.

It is not at all clear how all this is meant to help employers and investors attempting to weigh the probability of a no-deal Brexit - though it appears to have averted the risk of a rash of resignations on Wednesday.

“There was broad cabinet agreement that this was the way to proceed,” said her spokesman.

Updated at 2.54pm GMT

2.33pm GMT

The SNP’s Peter Grant asks what will happen if MPs vote against both no deal and against extending article 50. Is it any coincidence that the day ahead is the Ides of March?

May says the Commons will have decisions to take.

Updated at 2.51pm GMT

2.32pm GMT

Back in the Commons the Plaid Cymru MP Jonathan Edwards asks May to confirm that under her plan, if MPs vote to rule out no deal, and vote for an extension, the government will then enter an extension with no deal again an option. This is “swimming round in circles”, he says.

May says she wants MPs to back her deal.

Updated at 2.50pm GMT

2.30pm GMT

Theresa Villiers, a leading Tory Brexiter, told the World at One that, although the prospect of an article 50 extension was “frustrating”, the overall position had not changed significantly. She explained:

It’s frustrating that the prime minister is partially backtracking on her repeated statements that we would leave on March 29.

But fundamentally it doesn’t change the challenge that she has - she needs to get changes to the withdrawal treaty before it is capable of commanding support in parliament.

She needs to replace the Northern Ireland backstop with alternative arrangements which don’t have the flaws of the withdrawal treaty at present.

Villiers also said that, without a binding change to the withdrawal agreement, Theresa May’s deal would not pass.

Without binding treaty change it is hard to see how the prime minister gets her majority and overturns what was the most significant defeat for any government ever in the history of parliament.
